newsitem.title: TURKEY: Iraq says Turkey can help implement oil deal.
newsitem.headline: Iraq says Turkey can help implement oil deal.

text.p: Iraqi Trade Minister Mohammed Mehdi Saleh on Monday sought Turkish pressure on the United States and Britain to have the suspended U.N. oil-for-food deal implemented.

"Turkey and other nations can pressure Britain and the United States and have the (U.N.) resolution 986 implemented immediately," Saleh was quoted as saying by Anatolian news agency after meeting Turkish State Minister Cemil Tunc.

Saleh, who arrived in Ankara ahead of an Islamic Conference Organisation meeting on Tuesday in Istanbul, said the six-year-old U.N. trade embargo on Iraq had caused losses worth $120 billion to his country but also hurt Turkey.
"The embargo has harmed both the Iraqi and Turkish peoples while the United States was following its own interests," Saleh said.
Iraq accepted U.N. terms in May for an oil-for-food plan that would allow Baghdad to sell oil worth $2 billion over six months to buy humanitarian supplies.

But the United Nations suspended implementation after the Iraqi army's drive in late August into the northern part of the country to help one Kurdish group against another. The Iraqi army had been barred from the area since 1991.
Turkish officials put its own trade losses from the embargo on Iraq, which was its top oil supplier and third largest trade partner before the 1990-91 Gulf crisis, at about $27 billion.
Turkish State Minister Tunc said the embargo had dealt a severe blow to Turkey's southeast, which depended on trade with Iraq before the Gulf crisis.
